Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Expectation2: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation2: Cloud tops are rising quickly, and several pilots await revised climb instructions.
Story: My phone buzzes again, lighting up with another message from Alex: “We need to talk. I can’t keep doing this.” My chest tightens. We’ve argued about money every night this week, and I know he expects me to fix things, to smooth it over, to be the understanding girlfriend who can resolve our mess. But right now, I’m staring at a radar screen, watching cloud tops surge higher than forecasted, and three pilots are waiting for my revised climb instructions. My headset crackles with their voices, each one depending on me to keep them safe, to communicate clearly and quickly. I glance at my phone, then back at the screen, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. Alex wants answers, reassurance, a sign that I care. The pilots need precision, calm, and my undivided attention. My heart pounds as I try to steady my breathing, torn between the storm outside and the storm at home, knowing I can’t be in both places at once.
